speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, speaking on behalf of the people of Laval-des-Rapides, I wish to express before the House my indignation about some comments made by the Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson) before members of the National Editors and Writers Society in Toronto last week. According to reports, the Minister of Finance asked the media to apply restraint in their articles on the Government's intentions to cut back social programs, so as to avoid creating a panic among recipients of family allowance and old age security payments.
Is the Minister now going to ask the media not to publish information on cutbacks in equalization payments so as not to create panic among provinces receiving such payments? If the information media and even parliamentarians no longer have a right to comment on the Government's policies, I wonder what kind of information the public will receive. Not the press but the Progressive Conservative Government decided to make cutbacks in social programs. It is clear that the Government wants to tamper, either directly or indirectly, with the universality of social programs, but it would prefer to keep it a secret.
If the Minister of Finance wants to reassure Canadians and allay the very real fears he raised among those benefiting from social programs, all he has to do is say publicly, and say it now, that universality will be fully maintained and that the Government does not intend to tax all benefits received, and then Canadians will breathe easier. Then there will be no question of creating panic among senior citizens and other beneficiaries of social programs, and the media will be able to do their work unhindered.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise to draw to the attention of the House an unfortunate situation which must be reviewed if the unemployment insurance system is to be considered fair and just to all workers. I refer to reports that the Commission's office in Barrie, Ontario, intends to appeal decisions of the local board referees interpreting the vacation pay, lay-off notices and unemployment insurance provisions in favour of the workers at Black and Decker.
The Liberals put into place a system and a mind set which consistently denied fair interpretations without the realization of a basic fact, that when a plant closes down completely it is not a case of a worker trying to beat the system but a case where the system must start working for the worker.
That same nonsense occurred in Midland, Ontario, when the RCA plant closed in 1982.
I ask the Minister of Employment and Immigration (Miss MacDonald) who, the House knows, dislikes technicalities which persecute the unfortunate, to have her officials investigate this fully before the Government takes any further appeal procedures.
I also ask the Minister, who, I know, is concerned about the shambles in which the Liberals left the system, to consider a complete review of the vacation pay, lay-off notices and unemployment insurance provisions.

STATUS OF WOMEN
subsubtopic: ROLE OF WOMEN IN THIRD WORLD DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in 1975 the United Nations officially opened the International Decade for Women by highlighting the problems of women in the Third World. Unfortunately, as the decade draws to a close, many of the problems persist.
An area of particular importance is the role of women in development. If effective and lasting development is to take place in the Third World, women must be integrated into the process. For example, many African agricultural training projects fail, simply because they focus on men, ignoring the fact that women do 70 per cent of the agricultural work. In addition, while two-thirds of the world's 800 million illiterate are women, women are often left out of literacy training programs. This can no longer go on if proper and dynamic development is to take place.
Fortunately, some positive steps have been taken. The OECD has established guidelines that strongly remind member agencies to treat women in development as the major issue. In Canada, CIDA and Match International have also played a significant role in encouraging development initiatives by women.
Progress has been made, but the problems of women in development, and indeed the problems of development as a whole, if not dealt with more effectively, will be with us long after the decade of women is over.

AGRICULTURE
subsubtopic: IMPORTATION OF BEEF FROM DENMARK AND IRELAND- EFFECT ON CANADIAN FARMERS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this fall, millions and millions of pounds of subsidized beef have been dumped on the Canadian market by countries in the European Economic Community, such as Denmark and Ireland. Over 45 million pounds of beef, subsidized up to 50 cents a pound, are driving down the price that our Canadian beef producers receive for their product.
[DOT] (mo)
The Government promised in the election campaign "an effective fast track tariff policy, so that responsive action could be taken to protect producers by imposing import restrictions when necessary". Yet today, Mr. Speaker, there is not a single piece of legislation to implement this election promise or any other Tory election promise for agriculture, on the Order Paper of this House.
A recent report of the Farm Credit Corporation showed that 39,000 farmers across Canada are under serious financial stress this winter due to low commodity prices, and 1,700 are actually facing total financial collapse. Mr. Speaker, the Government was elected three months ago but has still not taken action to stop this dumping of subsidized beef by the European Economic Community countries. The Government must move immediately to stop this unfair practice which is driving more and more of our Canadian beef producers into bankruptcy.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise to commend the Secretary of State for External Affairs (Mr. Clark) on his apparent active inquiry into Canada's need for direct representation in Nicaragua.
As the only Member of this House to witness the November 4 election held in Nicaragua, I assure my honourable colleagues that that election was a genuine, democratic act of choice by the people of Nicaragua. It was not perfect, as elections in Canada are not perfect. However, it formally confirms what has already been plain to observers-the fact that the Government of Nicaragua is controlled by nobody but the people of Nicaragua.
As a sovereign state, engaged in desperate defence against the most powerful state in the world, Nicaragua has sent an ambassador to Canada, and deserves to receive an ambassador from Canada. Therefore I welcome the Minister's report inquiry into the pros and cons of establishing permanent representation there. The Globe and Mail today sums it up well:
The establishment of a permanent Canadian "presence" there is highly desirable-
November 30, 1984

The absence of an embassy in Nicaragua leaves Canada dependent on the U.S. for more than information. Canadians resident in Nicaragua are asked to register with the American embassy. If there were an invasion, Canadians would have to rely upon the invader's embassy to co-ordinate their evacuation. That should be an embarrassment-to Joe Clark and to Canada.
1 urge the Minister to act soon to help head off the dangers of war in Central America.

subsubtopic: PLIGHT OF JEWISH GROUP IN ETHIOPIA
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, a large number of my constituents would like to commend the Secretary of State for External Affairs (Mr. Clark) for his prompt and exemplary action in delivering aid to Ethiopia amounting to $50 million.
There are some sectors of the Ethiopian Community, however, which require prompt and immediate action, particularly the Falashas, one of the oldest Jewish groups, which faces the possibility of ceasing to exist as a cultural entity.
A group of my constituents who recently returned from Ethiopia, reported that Canadian aid was being hampered due to the civil war raging between the Ethiopian, Eritrean and Somalian factions. Consequently, I urge the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) to direct the Secretary of State for External Affairs to instruct our Ambassador to the United Nations to seek an emergency session at the U.N. in order to propose an immediate 30-day truce during the upcoming holiday season, among the warring factions in Ethiopia so that Canada, in concert with other nations, could quickly organize an airlift and food drops to the inaccessible and war areas of Ethiopia to avoid an even greater disaster.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1984-85 (No. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I thank the Hon. Member for the question. I had indicated that I did not have time to go into that issue. The point is that when preferential hiring regulations are introduced into the system, they sometimes discriminate against the most needy.
I am pleased that the Minister of Employment and Immigration is in the House to hear what I have to say. Let us examine the two employment programs and their hiring regulations which the Minister announced to the House.
According to the Canada Works Program, first, one must run out of unemployment insurance in order to qualify for that first category to be hired. One has to be drawing unemployment insurance in order to qualify under the second category. Those regulations were brought about because of the NEED program which was established in consultation with the provincial governments. Second, according to Section 38, one must be drawing unemployment insurance in order to be hired on one of those projects.
Under the new direction that the Department is now taking in an attempt to save $250 million through increased interviews for placing people into jobs, as the Minister of Finance and the Minister of Employment and Immigration have said, there would obviously be preference given to those people who are drawing unemployment insurance in placing them in those jobs.
November 30, 1984

I recently had a case of a widow with one daughter and two sons. The widow works one week out of a month at a corner-store. She cannot get hired because she is not drawing unemployment insurance, but she has worked in the previous eight weeks, which is another condition for hiring. The daughter graduated from trade school after a secretarial and bookkeeping course but she has never drawn unemployment insurance before and, therefore, is in the last category for hiring under any works program.
This widow also has two sons at home who are aged 18 and 21. Since they have not worked before they do not qualify for those programs.
The Minister says that the business community has identified approximately 170,000 jobs so far. If the Minister wishes to take people off unemployment insurance and save $250 million, it will be necessary to have an unemployment insurance officer send notices to those people indicating where those jobs are. Again, there is that built-in discrimination against first time workers or people looking for a job.
This is a very serious situation because we must realize that when someone reaches 18 years of age the family allowance payment stops. Furthermore, in most provinces, those who are 18 or older and living at home cannot even get welfare. This means, in the case of the widow with the daughter who just graduated from trade school and the two sons at home, that she is stricted to the small amount of income that she gets one week out of a month, plus the widows' allowance in Newfoundland on which even one person cannot live, let alone support three children.
Restricted hiring practices have evolved over a period of time because of various inputs, primarily by provincial governments that were more interested in work programs and getting people off welfare than in anything else. This is built into the system. The new measures introduced by The Minister of Employment and Immigration and the Minister of Finance in saving the $200 million will now really drive in a wedge and create poverty and give no hope for that time fellow or girl looking for the first job. It is outright, plain discrimination. There are no other words for it.
The Government should change its mind. The people which the Government consults are not these very people. The people the Government consults are perhaps the stiff-shirted, carpet-ed-up-to-your-knees people who think they have the answers to everything. The Government has to turn around and change direction. It should not be saving money on the backs of the poor. It should not have promised the world to these people in every single Department. There were 388 financial promises made. Perhaps two or three of those promises have been kept, but then the cuts came which affected only the poor people. The people will not put up with it. speechtext:
I am rising to speak on the legislation which is currently before the House, namely the borrowing authority Bill C-l 1 whereby the Conservative Government is seeking authority to borrow some $7.3 billion in the present fiscal year 1984-85, and, going beyond that, to borrow some $16 billion for fiscal 1985-86.
My colleague, the Hon. Member for Kamloops-Shuswap (Mr. Riis), on Wednesday last moved a reasoned amendment,

November 30, 1984
Borrowing Authority
which was accepted by the Chair. The substance was to call upon the House to recognize in effect that what the Government is seeking is the authority to borrow money far beyond what is reasonable in the circumstances. The amendment proposed by my colleague, the finance spokesman for the Party, reads:
That this House holds the opinion that the granting of an authority for the borrowing of a sum greater than the amount which is required to meet the Government's needs to the end of the current fiscal year is objectionable in principle-
The amendment goes on to suggest that the House should not give second reading to Bill C-l 1.
It was not particularly surprising that that reasoned amendment was found to be in order by the Chair. That motion was identical to the motion which was proposed by the Conservative Party when it was in Opposition in 1982. On July 19, 1982, the Official Opposition moved the very motion now before the House.
We have seen in the course of the last seven or eight weeks some very dramatic reversals of policy by the Conservatives now that they are in government. Surely one cannot imagine a more dramatic reversal than what is now happening in this House when the Conservative Government comes before Parliament and says to us effectively, "Give us the money that we need. Let us borrow money, not only for the current fiscal year up to March 31, 1985, but give us an extra $16 billion on top of that for the next fiscal year. We are not going to tell you how it is going to be spent". We all know that the Main Estimates are not tabled until next spring. "We are not going to tell you how it is going to be spent" effectively says that the Conservatives want us to trust that they will spend that $16 billion wisely and with care.
In assessing the request of the Government to trust it, in assessing the Government's request for an additional $16 billion in borrowing authority in the fiscal year 1985-86, I suggest it is appropriate that we look effectively at the requirements for this fiscal year and look at the Government's policies with respect to expenditure, cuts in programs, in services, in increases in taxes for this fiscal year. Then, as Members of the House, we should ask ourselves whether that record warrants the kind of trust we are being asked to give to this Government and whether it gives rise to the confidence that the Government will spend that money wisely.
I suggest the opposite is the case, Mr. Speaker, that the fiscal record of this Government so far is quite the reverse. We should be extremely concerned, if this Government is to be granted that kind of authority, whether it will spend wisely, because we believe the Government will spend according to the priorities of its friends in the corporate sector in the business community. If we need any evidence whatsoever that the big business community is leading this Government around by the nose and effectively calling the economic tune for this Government, we do not have to look further than the announcement made by the Minister of Labour (Mr. McKnight) who said that the changes which this Parliament passed to the Canada Labour Code, which would ensure conditions of work are safer
and healthier, are not going to be implemented for another two years. That is a shameful decision by this Government and a denial of the rights, not just of 300,000 public servants who have no protection whatosever but of many, many other thousands of workers within federal jurisdiction.
It is quite obvious that the reason for that decision was the fact that the corporate sector fought this Bill when it was presented to Parliament. The corporate sector fought it when the Bill went to committee, and now it has found some allies on the government side of the House. It does not take two years to draft regulations. It does not take two years to draft regulations that would require employers to ensure that working conditions are safe and not hazardous. That is the Government which is asking us now to trust it, to trust that it will spend the $16 billion it is asking for wisely.
The Secretary of State for External Affairs (Mr. Clark) is not in the House at the present time. At the time the Conservative Party proposed the amendment which is now before the House in identical form, the Secretary of State for External Affairs said:
The first amendment we offered was to decline second reading of this Bill. There is a well established principle that Parliament only provides sufficient borrowing authority to a Government to allow it to finance its operations within the current fiscal year. It is clear from the figures in the bill and from the statement by the Minister of State for Finance (Mr. Bussicres) in response to my question yesterday that the government has every intention of this borrowing authority spilling over into 1983-84.
This is all the more reprehensible because the government has not given us any projections about what will happen in 1983-84.
What has changed? What has been the dramatic change from the time when the Conservatives were in Opposition, when what was being done was reprehensible and breached all the finest traditions of Parliament, to today when the Conservatives come before Parliament and propose exactly the same thing?
There are no projections whatsoever as to how this money will be spent. Indeed, we in this Party have asked repeatedly not only for projections with respect to how the moneys are to be spent in the next fiscal year, but for statements of the impact of the decisions which have already been announced by the Government. I suspect that this impact will be very severe on my constituents and on the constituents of all Members of the House, and so it will be with respect to jobs and cuts in services. The impact will be devastating.
The Government comes before us and says, "Forget about what we said in Opposition, forget about our principles and everything for which we stood when we were in opposition. We are in government now and those principes do not matter any more". That is the kind of action which brings the promises of politicians into disrepute. There have been a number of similar actions by the Government which I believe are most unworthy of a Party elected on a mandate of change, a mandate to provide jobs or a mandate which indicated that job creation would be the top priority.
November 30, 1984

What has happened to the top priority of job creation? It has been transformed into a very different priority, that is, this Government's slavish obsession with the deficit, with cutting the deficit.
During the federal election campaign, far from dwelling on the deficit, the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) indicated that his top priority was job, jobs, jobs. Yet that priority appears to have vanished in the economic statements of this Government in recent weeks. According to the Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson), it is now clear that we have a new priority, and that priority is cutting the deficit. This is somehow supposed to be the panacea. Cutting the deficit will be the great panacea which results in restoration of business confidence, which in turn results in more investment, which in turn theoretically will provide jobs. It just does not work that way. We do not have to look very far to see the evidence that that kind of economic theory, that discredited economic theory, is totally unworkable in practice.
That theory has been implemented in my own Province of British Columbia with a very dramatic and harsh impact. Thousands of people have been thrown out of work, both those in the Public Service and others. Services have been cut. In many cases essential services have been cut. There are line-ups at food banks in British Columbia; 2,000 to 3,000 people are lining up for food in that province. That is from a government that has the same basic economic thrust as the Conservative Government is presenting to Parliament and for which it is requesting support. The old trickle-down theory that somehow if we reduce the deficit in turn the additional moneys which are liberated will be spent by the corporate sector to create jobs, was discredited in the 1930s during the depression. In fact, it was the implementation of similar theories which led to the worst depression in modern economic history. A whole generation of Canadians were unable to find work. We know very well what happened to the government of R. B. Bennett for its ineptness in handling the crisis of unemployment in the 1930s.
It is interesting to note that in its obsession with the deficit, the Government is ignoring the fact that a number of jurisdictions have increased the deficit on a short-term basis with the objective of providing jobs for their people. That has been done in a successful manner. Instead of this obsession with the deficit, the Government should look far more closely at its fundamental priority, as stated during the election. Surely that priority must be the creation of jobs for some two million Canadians who are without work today, half of whom are young people. Rather than that priority, we hear the Canadian Federation of Independent Business suggesting that there are 170,000 jobs in Canada just waiting to be filled. I suggest that the Federation should get serious. If it really believes that there are 170,000 jobs out there, employers who claim that they cannot find people to fill those jobs should come forward and give the details of those jobs, because I suggest they would be flooded with applications from many desperate people who are trying to find work.
Borrowing Authority
Members of Parliament should visit Canada employment centres in their communities to see the long line-ups of people, many of whom are desperate, are losing hope and would take virtually anything in order to survive. We are not just talking about the economic hardship of being out of work, but the loss of dignity involved as well, the lack of self-respect and the feeling which are part and parcel of losing a job in today's society.
During Questions Period today I raised a question with the Minister of Employment and Immigration (Miss MacDonald) about the fact that the Government, in its new-found obsession with the deficit, intends to reduce the payments made available to individuals who lose their jobs and have negotiated some form of severance pay package or early retirement scheme. In my constituency of Burnaby, almost 400 people will be thrown out of work at the end of January. Fortunately they were able to negotiate some form of early retirement benefits or severance benefits, which after all is just a form of deferred income. The Government is saying to those 400 men and women, many of whom are in their fifties and will find it very difficult to find alternate employment, that their monthly pay package as a result of its program will be cut dramatically.
I do not believe that is a just and fair program. I do not think we should be attempting to cut the deficit on the backs of working people or people who have been thrown out of their jobs and are attempting to survive and to feed their families. We did not hear anything about that during the last election campaign. Instead, we heard talk of jobs, jobs, jobs. However, that has been abandoned by the Government.
We know as well that women are being disproportionately affected by the crisis in unemployment. With the advent of new technologies, women are being increasingly relegated to the role of part-time workers. There are serious cut-backs in access to child care, which has a devastating impact upon the ability of women to participate as equal partners in the work place. Increasingly we are hearing the cry that somehow women are secondary wage earners. Surely in society today women must be accepted as full partners economically, socially and in every other way. The effect of this Government's economic policies is particularly harsh on working women as well as on single parents who are struggling to survive on incomes which are often below the poverty level.
If the Government were serious about its commitment to job creation and its commitment to reducing the deficit in a manner which is sensitive to human needs and concerns, why does it not take a look as well, at the possibility of increasing revenues? There is a great opportunity to do so by ensuring that the taxation system is fairer and more equitable. There are far too many loopholes which allow Canadians with incomes in excess of $70,000, $80,000 and $100,000 per year to avoid the payment of any income taxes whatsoever.
We all remember the promises of the Prime Minister, in response to the prodding of my own Leader, that he would introduce a handsome minimum tax. While we must accept the principle of a minimum tax, we have to look beyond that and fundamentally restructure the taxation system in this

November 30, 1984
Borrowing Authority
country. We have to look at an elimination of some of the glaring loopholes that favour the wealthy as opposed to the poor. We have to look at making sure that the corporate sector pays its fair share of taxes. Its share of the over-all tax burden has dropped dramatically since 1950. We must look as well at the whole question of tax exemptions and the regressive nature of many of these tax exemptions. A child tax exemption is of far greater benefit to someone earning $100,000 a year than it is to a single parent who, as I said before, is struggling to survive.
This Government is asking for a blank cheque. I do not believe that its policies as enunciated to date are such that we should trust it with the extra $16 billion that it is asking for in the next fiscal year without any projection whatsoever as to what it will be spent on. We do not know, for example, whether it intends to cut back on equalization payments to the provinces in the areas of health care, legal aid and postsecondary education.
We have seen the devastating effect in the Province of British Columbia of cut-backs in post-secondary education. Far from reducing equalization payments to the provinces, we should be ensuring that the money which the federal Government designates to the provinces for health care is in fact spent on health care, and money which it designates for post-secondary education is spent on post-secondary education.
In the whole question of cutting the deficit, we have to look as well at the sacred cow of military expenditures. Somehow or other when we ask people to make sacrifices, equity is lacking. We do not ask that sacred cow to make sacrifices, but we do ask the poor, those without work, and the powerless in society to make the sacrifices. Any notion of equity and fairness surely requires that those most able to bear the burden of sacrifice are called upon to bear that burden first.
I see that my time for my speech on this Bill is just about up. I appeal to government members to recognize that what is being asked for in the proposal before the House today was deemed by them to be unacceptable, reprehensible and wrong when they were in Opposition. I appeal to those Members to explain to this House how what was wrong, reprehensible and unparliamentary in 1982 when done by a Liberal government can suddenly become acceptable and justifiable today.

taxes and tremendous income taxes. Although the people recognize that taxes are necessary for the government and society today, they do have the sense that this money is not being used as wisely as it should be.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1984-85 (No. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Canadians voted for a change on September 4 and positive, progressive change is well under way. For the first time in many years, Canada has a Government that is realistically facing our nation's serious financial problems. We are telling Canadians in an honest and responsible manner that this country can no longer run up massive deficits year after year.
The facts are quite simple. By the end of 1984-85, the net public debt which is the accumulation of past budgetary deficits, is likely to reach nearly $190 billion, an incomprehensible amount. The national debt is growing faster than the economy. In relation to the size of the economy, net public debt will have increased from 16.6 per cent of GNP in 1974-75 to 45.2 per cent in 1984-85. In simple terms, our budgetary deficit is more than 7 per cent of Gross Domestic Product and has grown tenfold since 1967. In addition, one-half of current government borrowing is earmarked for interest payments alone.
In its September issue of Observer, the OECD assessed Canada's deficit as being uncomfortably high. It went on to say that the priority of Canada's Government should now be to reduce the federal deficit.
Our Party realizes that we must bring down the deficit in order to bring down interest rates, which would bring down the unemployment rate. We all know that as the deficit rises, so do interest rates. For each one percentage point increase in interest rates, the public debt charges rise nearly $1 billion. Thus we have a vicious cycle. This ever-increasing debt load is shattering confidence in our economy and suffocating growth and job creation. By successfully combatting the deficit and opening up investment opportunities, we will be continually fighting unemployment.
We have a Government that wishes to consult with the people. I would like to report to the House that in Scarborough that consultative process has already begun. The four Members of Parliament from the City of Scarborough who are sitting on the government side have been consulting with local politicians, the mayor, the controllers and the aldermen to look at ways and means of getting people back to work. The Mayor of Scarborough called me on September 5 and asked when we could get together to have that consultation. We have met on several occasions.
The people of Canada and the people of Scarborough want to be heard and want to be heard in the House. My hon. friend said that only the people who are up to their knees in carpet are being heard. That is not true. The people of Canada are being heard through their representatives on this side of the House.
People want to work. Young people and those people who are mature workers have lost their jobs because of interest rates, businesses going out of business, bankruptcies, lay-offs and investment which is flowing out of this country. This Government has a determination to develop inner confidence and a sense of purpose. With that sense of purpose and that confidence, we will make Canadian people winners by maintaining security with meaningful employment.
We must demonstrate to entrepreneurs and to investors that Canada is ready for business once again. Above all, immediate measures must be taken to stimulate economic growth and job creation. How can we do this? By reducing the deficit in a fair and honest manner. I would like to read a recent editorial from the International Herald Tribune which contrasts our approach with the approach taken by U.S. President Ronald Reagan. The aricle is dated Saturday-Sunday, November 17-18, 1984 and reads as follows:
Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has denounced the huge budget deficit in the most explicit terms. His finance minister, Michael Wilson, warned last week that Canada cannot expect just to grow out of it. "The simple fact is," he said, "that the mounting federal debt has become a powerful obstacle to growth and to private-sector job creation." That touches a couple of points upon which President Reagan and his secretary of the Treasury, Donald Regan, remain conspicuously ambivalent.
Another difference: Mr. Mulroney has gone to some lengths to assure Canadians that he is not going to try to knock holes in their comprehensive, extensive system of social benefits. On October 22, 1968, the Hon. Edgar Benson, in his Budget address said:
We intend to continue severe restraint upon those direct expenditure programs under the Government's control, eliminating what is obsolete, and permitting only the degree of growth that is essential.

There can be no weakening in our determination to keep expenditures under tight control.
Tight control Mr. Speaker, some control. The deficit that year was $12 billion. In his October 20, 1980 Budget address to the House, the then Minister of Finance said:

Great restraint over expenditures, Mr. Speaker, some restraint. It gets better. On November 12, 1981, the former Finance Minister, in his Budget address to this House, which we all remember very well, said:
This budget has three themes: restraint, equity, and economic renewal .. . For our part, I believe we must reduce our deficit and our borrowing requirements substantially.
Some restraint, some reduction, Mr. Speaker. The deficit that year was $15 billion. In 1981, we slowly slipped into the worst recession in our country's history.
On April 19, 1983, in the Budget address to the House of Commons by the then Minister of Finance, he said:
This is a fiscally responsible budget.
Some budget, Mr. Speaker, some responsibility. The deficit that year was $31.8. That is the end of our little walk down memory lane.
This summer during the election, Barbara Frum said on The Journal, "There seems to be a fundamental flaw in our economy". Mr. Speaker, she was dead right. Our nation's affairs have been seriously mismanaged and this has put us in the bind we are in today. We are living with the tremendous government waste of past administrations. Need I remind the House of Consolidated Computer at $125 million, or Maislin Industries at $34 million, or Canadair and many others?
I have received representations from business leaders, interest groups and individuals in my riding. I sense that a new air of optimism has blown across the country. Our chariot of fire has been lit by people from all regions, from all towns and cities in every Canadian province. This is what we as a Government can now build on. We cannot do it without some fiscal manoeuvrability. The federal deficit and the accumulated national debt has reached unmanageable proportions. Never in Canadian history has so much been owed by so many

to so few. We have inherited this and we will have to make some difficult decisions to manage it effectively. As the House knows, we have already made some decisions and we will have to make some more.
On May 7, 1984, Professor Lipsey, senior economic adviser of the C.D. Howe Institute, gave a speech at the Conference Board of Canada financial conference in Toronto. He said:
The best contribution that public policy can make to removing unemployment is, first, to get the deficit quickly under control so that a better balance of less expansionary fiscal policy and a more expansionary monetary policy can be adopted.
Professor Lipsey went on to say:
Once we realize that cutting public sector deficits allows easier monetary policy we will have taken a fundamentally important step towards creating a more receptive climate for investment and risk taking.
The House knows that our priority is to reduce the federal deficit, and we will. We will target our talent and dollars at winners or potential winners to help our lost generation of young people find jobs. To do this we will need the co-operation and support of the private sector. In my opinion, there is nothing wrong with that.
The Premier of Ontario, when speaking of the deficit recently, said, "You cannot take more out of something than you put into it". We are now trying to right the wrongs of Liberal pasts.
Since 1980, the investment, tax and energy policies of the former Liberal government have caused a flight of job-creating capital from this country that is without precedent in our history. Seventeen billion dollars of direct investment capital has left Canada which could have been used to strengthen our capital base and create jobs. Liberal programs such as the national energy policy and the Foreign Investment Review Agency were catalysts which set off a chain reaction of destruction throughout our economy, helping to turn a global recession into a made-in-Canada catastrophe.
In 1980, the Liberals told Canadians they would buy back Canada, that foreign investors were no longer welcome. They did not really buy back Canada, Mr. Speaker; they borrowed it back, replacing foreign equity with foreign debt. That huge outflow of equity, much of it Canadian, has been a major reason why our dollar has fallen from 88 cents to 75 cents American since the 1980 election. That outflow of equity is also one reason for our high interest rates. If Canada had not offset that outflow of cheap equity with an inflow of expensive debt, our dollar would have sunk like a stone.
We now have a wonderful opportunity to show domestic and international investors that Canada is still an excellent place in which to invest. In short, encouraging investment in this country is a top priority for our Government.

If we do not borrow these funds, the Government will be forced to break its undertaking to Canadians and to Canadian institutions. We have financial, legal and moral obligations. If we do

Mr. Speaker, I rise in support of Bill C-ll. I have been hearing since early this morning about the devastation that we have caused and the way we have wreaked havoc on the entire community. All we have asked for is a time for reflection to consider what has taken place. Since 1968, the good old days when we used to run surpluses at the end of each budgetary year, we have somehow been able to change the whole pattern of development. We are now running massive deficits approaching some $35 billion. We changed this pattern with the assistance of many Finance Ministers all of whom talked about restraint.
Deficits and jobs are of grave concern. I come from a riding that is 50 per cent ethnic in its nature. These are people who have come to Canada, many first generation newcomers from different lands. We have representatives of 39 ethnic communities. We have many visible minorities. They cannot quite seem to grasp what is going on. They came here filled with high hopes and aspirations, expecting a land of milk and honey. But now we have massive deficits and there are no jobs. We cannot keep spending as if there were no tomorrow. At some point we have to cause an interruption in that rapid growth that has been taking place, one that would run us right off the map.
A recent study in Ville St. Laurent, one of the two important cities that comprise my riding, showed that in some 100 ethnic families with an average of 5.2 members per family there was an unemployment rate of 72 per cent. This is appalling. They live in abominable conditions, conditions that are sub-human, and they have an income of $1,100 a month either through welfare or whatever other source. They want answers and they want answers quickly. Certainly they want job creation, the young people, the older people, and the rest.
I think it was a good beginning. We came to grips with the deficit. We are saying that before we allow any further growth in the deficit, let us control it, let us stop it. Let us take a look at what we are doing. Let us look at the high unemployment and inadequate investment. We must take a look at the erosion of confidence that has taken place and all of the personal hardship. How are we going to restore some confidence into this community? What are we going to do?
We have to begin with a proper program of restraint. I heard about the devastation we are causing. I can only assure the Hon. Member who has brought this matter to our attention that everything I have heard so far in the first few months is that everyone will be treated with fairness. We cut $1
Borrowing Authority
million from the budget of the National Film Board, which caused some hysteria. We asked the CBC to take a cut of $75 million, and the CBC instantly wanted to cut out some vital program.
I think those of us who ran hard this past year ran hard so that we can get here to create some accountability and responsibility in government. What we are really saying is: don't affect the services. Let us look at the way these services are being administered. Let us come to grips with the large bureaucracies, those 300 or 400 agencies that have never had any accountability and whose books have never been opened to public scrutiny.

In general, one out of six heads of households is out of work. They do not understand how we can continue to spend as if there were no tomorrow. Therefore, let us control our spending, put it on hold, while we consider ways of putting more people back to work. This will be shown by a renewed investment in our community by the creation of jobs.
As some Hon. Members will recall, Parliament has already granted borrowing authority amounting to $24.6 billion for the present year, an amount based on the previous government's requirements of $25.5 billion. However, we inherited financial requirements of $29.9 billion. This sorry plight, the mess left us, requires us to have supplementary borrowing authority for the current fiscal year. In addition, the new expenditures and the tax initiatives which the Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson) announced bring our projected requirements to $29.2 billion, $6 billion higher than estimated last summer.
What we are trying to do is to become a little more cost efficient. We want to make sure that there is an importance to what we are doing. We want to minimize the changes taking place in the community. There is a need to put our house in order. We have to limit the debt in order to do that. We have to reverse our direction and what effect it has had on our confidence and growth.
We have come through an era where government has played a very implicit role in the handling and management of business. It has been too involved. Many of us would like to see a little less government involvement. We would like to think that we can somehow get the government out of our bedrooms and put the initiative back into the private sector. Small businessmen are already burdened with far too much red tape and far too much bureaucracy. There are people who are innovative. Some of us are prepared to take risks. We have the competitive spirit. We feel the reins should be loosened somehow. This is the kind of view that is being taken in this reflective period.
What we promised through the summer campaign and "the time for change" on which we all ran, is that we would be in

Mr. Speaker, I would like to make a few comments regarding Bill C-ll which is before the House today. First I would like to provide some explanation to the questions which were asked this morning by the Hon. Member for Kamloops-Shuswap (Mr. Riis). He was complaining about the fact that we were asking for borrowing authority for the 1985-86 fiscal year, despite the precedent which was set in the House earlier this year by the Liberal Party when it tried to do exactly the same sort of thing. So there is a well-established precedent.
The Hon. Member gave some moral arguments against it, but 1 want to tell the House the real reason the NDP brought in this amendment. The real reason is that they want to recycle speakers. There are very few Members on that side of the House, and rightly so. The electorate of Canada has seen to that. The reason they introduced the amendment was so that they could recycle speakers over and over again.
I would like to speak about the Bill in a non-partisan way and look at it as objectively as possible. 1 have to admit that I am not particularly proud of the Bill we have before us today. The reason we are saddled with it is because of the previous administration. It resulted from the activities and mismanagement of the previous administration. It is hard to turn things around financially within a limited period of time.
I sometimes look upon the House of Commons, Mr. Speaker, as being something of a sausage machine. Material is fed into it, the handle is turned, but it might be six months or a year before anything comes out the other end. In the meantime, what one is dealing with is material which had been introduced by a previous government. We have already heard an explanation of this phenomenon with respect to the tax measures which were dealt with early in the life of the new Government. The tax measures resulted from proposals which had been made and laws which had been passed when the previous government had been in office.
Under this Bill, the Government is asking for a considerable amount of borrowing authority. We would like it to be much less than it is. We would expect that as our policies are carried into effect, as confidence grows in the country, as investments are made, and as jobs are created-and they are being created now-the amount of money which will need to be borrowed will become progressively less.
I feel it is important, Sir, that Parliament be vigilant in these affairs. One of the most important tasks before us as parliamentarians is the guardianship of the public purse. I welcome a reasonably long debate on this issue. I do not believe that the Government of the day ought to try to rush through borrowing authority Bills, as the Liberals did in the past. We on this side are prepared to debate this issue for as long as necessary. We must deal with it in a timely manner, but we are prepared to devote the necessary time in order to listen to what other Members of Parliament have to say on the issue. It is important that they be heard.

In a debate of this nature there is an opportunity for the Opposition to do its proper job, to fulfil the role expected of it by the Canadian public. Unfortunately, however, in listening to the Hon. Members of the Opposition speak on this matter, it does not seem to me that they are doing their job that well. I listened very carefully to the speeches which have been presented and all we have heard is criticism, on the one hand, for requesting too much borrowing authority and, on the other hand, criticism for looking after the public purse and cutting down on areas where expenditures are not really necessary.
We are criticized for dealing with the nation's finances in a prudent fashion. The Opposition cannot have it both ways; it cannot chide us for spending too much and condemn us for spending too little. There is a duplicity in ideas which is very apparent when you listen to Hon. Members opposite. There is a lack of perspicacity in their argument. I would hope that as time progresses and these important financial subjects come up again, the quality of debate from the other side of the House will improve.
There has been some criticism with which I would have to agree in that it might have been advantageous for certain documents to be tabled at the same time as this Bill was brought before the House. But if one listened carefully to the presentation of the Hon. Minister of State for Finance (Mrs. McDougall), one would find that most of the figures which are needed in order to make a rational judgment of the merits of this Bill are included therein. However, it might have been better if these could have been consolidated on paper.
What Hon. Members of Parliament would undoubtedly like to know when they are discussing a matter such as this is the number of presently outstanding borrowing authorities and where they stand. They would like to see a computation of the financial requirements of the Government and to have available to them a synopsis of the existing debt of the Government of Canada. I am sure those Hon. Members would like to have some idea of the Government's borrowing plan for the months ahead. Therefore, my request of the Minister of State for Finance, when these types of occasions arise in the future, would be that this information-which is undoubtedly readily available in published form somewhere-be brought forward at the time of debate and presented to Members of Parliament so they will better be able to exercise their judgment when it comes to voting on the issue.
I would like now to examine the Bill and consider dispassionately what it requests in the way of borrowing authority and whether these requests are reasonable under the circumstances. In Part I of the Bill the Government is requesting the additional borrowing authority of some $7.3 billion to the end of this fiscal year. The best estimate - and it can only be an estimate - of the financial requirements to the end of March, 1985 is some $29.9 billion, within an existing borrowing authority of $24.6 billion. That would give the total of $31.9 billion. Therefore, the Government is requesting total borrowing authority of $31.9 billion. It has demonstrated financial requirements of some $29.9 billion. This gives the Government some $2 billion of leeway. I believe it is called "reserve" in the

November 30, 1984
Borrowing Authority
official terminology. When I sat on the other side of the House, I used to call it the "slush fund". However, under the circumstances, Sir, I do not feel we can say that that request is in any way unreasonable. I feel it is necessary to have some amount of reserve and $2 billion is certainly not unreasonable.
Nor, Sir, is it unreasonable that the request be made that that borrowing authority carry over unexpired at the end of the fiscal year; that it not lapse at that time. I would object, and have objected in the past, if the Government of the day asked for excessive amounts of reserve or excessive amounts which could be taken over the financial year end and used in the new year. But $2 billion can in no way be considered an unreasonable amount. It is very obvious that if we are going to plan ahead the amounts of money we will need to borrow in April or May, we must have that leeway.
Part II of the Bill requests an amount of $16 billion borrowing authority for the following fiscal year. If one looks at the projections, as far as they can be put together, this should hold the Government over until some time in the fall of next year; that is, if the projections are reasonably accurate. Let us hope, Sir, that we will not require that amount to tide us over until October or November of next year. Let us hope that the Government will not fully have to utilize that borrowing authority up until that time.
The idea in the Bill is not to preclude Parliament looking at necessary borrowing authorities again for the 1985-1986 fiscal year, but to allow the Government to go ahead and conduct its borrowing in an orderly way in the market-place until the end of summer. Then when Parliament comes back in September, the aditional borrowing authority for the balance of that fiscal year-which will undoubtedly be required-can be dealt with at that time and the matter will again be brought before Parliament. Hon. Members opposite and on this side will then have a chance to zero in on the way the Government is conducting its affairs. They will be able to say whether, in their opinion, the requested amount is unreasonable.
I have no hesitation in supporting Bill C-11 which has been brought forward today. I would hope that when we are discussing this matter again this time next year, the requested amounts will not be as large as those which are before us today. I have every expectation that because of the policies being pursued by the new Government and the new Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson), capably assisted by the new Minister of State for Finance, this will indeed be the case and the request at that time will be for a much lesser amount than that requested today.
If we get back to discussion on the main motion I will have the opportunity again to speak on this matter. There are two other areas which I would like to address. One is borrowing requirements with regard to capital amounts versus current account amounts. I would like to discuss when it makes sense to borrow money and when it does not make sense. I would like to look at the Government record with regard to borrowing for current account purposes.
The second matter which I would like to address in the future is that of foreign borrowing. In the speech of the Minister of State for Finance it was noted that some $1 billion had been borrowed in foreign currencies. There may be some danger in that type of borrowing activity. The amount at the present time is not really that great, but we do not want to follow the same route as some foreign countries have. They have borrowed very heavily in denominations of currencies not their own. That is just a matter of advance notice, Mr. Speaker. Thank you very much for the opportunity to speak on Bill C-l 1 this afternoon.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Hon. Member for Scarborough Centre (Mrs. Browes) spoke this morning on this Bill. I agree with many of the points she made. As the Hon. Member for Western Arctic (Mr. Nickerson) indicated, we do not really like the idea of borrowing. That is not the way we would like to see the Government operate ideally. No one likes to borrow but we recognize that it is necessary at times. In fact, at this particular time we realize that we are atoning for the fiscal irresponsibility of the previous government which ran up this deficit. It allowed it to increase as it allowed spending to increase with unbridled passion.
We are familiar with the figures. The deficit of SI90 billion has been accumulated at $34.5 billion a year. Just as in our private lives or business lives, we would not go to the bank to borrow money unless we understood how we would repay it. We realize that in the long term that is the kind of government we need in this country. We need a government that is fiscally accountable and fiscally responsible. We have not had the opportunity to see such a government for many years.
Indeed, if we were to follow the practices of the previous government, the accumulated debt by 1990 would reach such an extent that each family in this country would owe $54,000. Consider what that would mean to every man, woman and child in this country.
Last weekend, I went to my constituency to discuss our plans for economic renewal and our agenda for the future. Many of my constituents told me that they know some changes will hurt but they supported the Government one hundred per cent. They said that in fact they would like to see us go even further. Some people came to me and asked if there was not a way that we might even be able to develop a concept whereby that debt could be repaid now so that, as individuals or families, we could repay that debt which is owed to this country as a result of the previous fiscal irresponsibility.
I believe that Canadians-certainly the people in my riding-are behind the changes we are making. We know that it will not be easy and that we will have to begin saying no to many things in the next four years. That is the responsibility of our Government and that is the direction in which we must go.
I believe Hon. Members would agree that within government spending there is overlap and duplication. I spent many years working for a provincial government and I know from my own personal experience that there is waste aplenty. I know from my years in the private sector dealing with government that there are many examples of waste and overlap with provincial jurisdictions.
The Right Hon. Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Turner) said on July 25 of this year that there are programs that are duplications and programs that are wasteful. He said that there are programs that are no longer useful, programs which

November 30, 1984
Borrowing Authority
no longer serve a purpose and that there is administration that is wasteful. He said that he would cut them down. Fortunately, he has not had that opportunty. We inherited that responsibility and we recognize it.
This afternoon the Hon. Member for Burnaby (Mr. Robinson) spoke to this Bill. He might be surprised to learn that I share with him his concern for social justice. I am sure there will be many occasions when we will have similar point of view on matters coming before the House.
However, I do not agree with him on his approach to economic renewal. I suppose that is part of the fundamental difference between Members on different sides of the House. I believe that in order to be fiscally responsible we must have to stay "stop". We must say no to further increases in government spending and take control of the situation. In my opinion, that is not only the moral and ethical route to take, it is also the correct economic policy.

speechtext: Let them eat cake.

I would like to ensure that every man, woman and child in this country at least had the opportunity to eat cake, but my approach would be quite different, if I may respond to the Hon. Member.
Obviously, we are saying in our economic agenda for renewal that job creation is the number one priority. But we differ from our colleagues about the appropriate way to create jobs in this country.
Personally, I am a great advocate of small business. I believe Hon. Members would agree that small business is a major contributor to the benefits that we enjoy. Companies with less than $2 million of sales-which is one definition of small business-comprise 96 per cent of the total number of businesses in this country. They employ between 4.5 million and 5.4 million Canadians. They are the largest employer of Canadians. We know that women are one of the largest generators of new small businesses in this country. When we encourage the small business sector we are also assisting women in greater numbers.
The measures which we are proposing and implementing now are measures which will support small business. It is not government that creates jobs. That is the wrong approach. It is Canadians who create jobs.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1984-85 (No. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Hear, hear!

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1984-85 (No. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
I know from my own experience and from talking to my constituents that Canadians will not do that unless they feel there is an opportunity to enjoy the benefits if they take such a risk. They are tired of the constraints that were put on small business by the previous regime. They want a system which will provide more opportunity to make investments, take risks and employ people in this country and thereby add to a healthy economy that we all hope to enjoy.
These are the little people of this country. These are the people whom this Government wants to support. They are the people who run the restaurants, the dry cleaning shops and
have new ideas for the development of new applications of software.
Whenever I visit my riding, men and women come to me with ideas for small businesses they would like to begin. As I said in my maiden speech a few weeks ago, they are not asking for handouts. They only want to know if the Government will create the kind of climate in which they can be free to operate and employ people. That is the approach that this Government is taking in the fiscal scheme of our economic agenda.
I believe that our concept of responsibility is also consistent with the approach of our Government. We want to encourage individual responsibility and corporate responsibility in this country. In order to do that we must enable people to be free to accept that responsibility.
For example, let us consider family life. How can we expect our children to accept responsibility if they are given a new car or brand-new clothes when they turn 16? I believe they must have a sense of realism just as others in this country want to
have a sense of realism.
During the past number of years people have come to believe that the Government, through its industrial grants and so on, would provide things for them. I would like to see some of that changed. This can be accomplished when our major emphasis is on providing a sound economic climate in which people are free to make investments and create economic wealth.
I believe that the measures that have been put forward in our economic agenda and in Bill C-ll are based on a society which encourages strength, freedom, responsibility and challenge. We are giving a challenge to all Canadians in these next four years. We are saying that we are ready to accept our responsibility to be more fiscally prudent. We are asking Canadians to take this opportunity and we are counting on them to create the jobs and the economic wealth in this country.
While we recognize the need to borrow these funds at this time, I look forward to the time within the next four years when Canadians will have taken the initiatives, made the investments and created the jobs. In the future we will be in a position to say that our borrowing requirements will be dramatically diminished and that our economy is healthy once again.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the question by my near neighbour and colleague from British Columbia. As the Hon. Member knows, I am not privy to any of the policy-making discussions in British Columbia. I do not know the basis on which that government made its decisions.
I do not agree with the Hon. Member for Burnaby (Mr. Robinson) on the reasons we are experiencing such economic difficulties in British Columbia. To my mind they are not coming about as a result of the government's policies, although the media might have people believe that. The difficulties we are experiencing in British Columbia are because of some fundamental difficulties in the resource industries which have traditionally been the basis of our economy, the forest industry particularly and the mining industry. As a result of lower international prices for our products, our inability in some cases to be competitive, we have not seen the kind of growth
Borrowing Authority
we should have. In fact we have seen the opposite. We have seen major cutbacks in those industries.
Perhaps my colleague recalls the report made by the B.C. Central Credit Union recently which indicates that the future for those industries still does not look too optimistic. We really cannot count on those industries to create the new jobs in British Columbia. Therefore, we must be looking at the development of alternatives, new kinds of industrial approaches, and new kinds of services.
The approaches that we are taking as a federal Government in cutting back and being fiscally responsible will send those signals to the private sector in British Columbia. This will assist private businessmen. They come to me every week when I am out there. They are the ones who will start to create those jobs and alternative industries in British Columbia which I hope and pray will bring back economic health to our province.

Well I hope to speak often in the House and be elected as many times as I can, a bit like you yourself, sir-
To get back to Bill C-201, Mr. Speaker, which is aimed at substituting for the word "Nouvelle-Ecosse", whenever it appears in statutes, regulations, reports, contracts, leases, permits, licences or other documents, the word "Nova Scotia". I think the repercussions are far greater than my hon. colleague would have it seem. I think it would be a very significant change for Quebecers and for all Canadian Francophones. Some terms are easily interchangeable, but, as was pointed out several times in the House in the course of the debate on the Hon. Member's bill, the term "Nouvelle-Ecosse" has become part of our vocabulary and our whole way of life, and frankly,
I think it would sound very odd to say that we were going to spend a holiday in "Nova Scotia", a term which for us has become associated with English, a language we respect and for which I have a great deal of admiration as a Canadian. I think that is basically where the problem lies.
There are indeed a number of terms that in the course of time have become practically bilingual. Others, however, have become associated with one language rather than another. As far as French Canada in general and Quebec in particular are concerned, I can assure the Hon. Member that the term "Nouvelle-Ecosse" is as firmly rooted in our vocabulary as Nova Scotia probably is in yours, because as far as I know, Anglophones do not refer to "New Scotland". In fact, the Latin term, and Latin is in fact an off shoot of Sanskrit from which Greek is derived and so we finally get to Latin which has provided the basis for our two languages ... I would remind the Hon. Member that in the English language, for which I have a great affection, about seventy or eighty per cent of the words are French, although pronounced differently. And so we have here a Latin name which as a result of history has to all intents and purposes become an English word.
1 repeat to my colleague that as far as we are concerned, "Nouvelle-Ecosse", in French is the official name. This is one of the things we learn in school. It is in our history books, and
there is nowhere any reference in our community or in our language, to "Nova Scotia". But there is reference everywhere to the beautiful province of "Nouvelle-Ecosse".
I would ask my colleague to consider that, in effect, this is more than a simple semantic issue in Canada. If, in the past, in some of the English-speaking provinces certain geographical names have been in French, in most cases this has come about through a consensus, whether it is in the United States or in any English-Speaking province of Canada that such French names have survived. This has been done out of habit. It is part of the heritage of those communities in areas with such specific names.
Therefore, in our view, which surely is shared by all my French-speaking colleagues from Quebec, and probably from elsewhere in Canada, the name "Nova Scotia" could definitely never be substituted to the French name "Nouvelle-Ecosse" in our language.
Let me stress that I appreciate the reasons why my colleague from Annapolis Valley-Hants introduced Bill C-201. I appreciate that it is important to him, in his language, that the name "Nova Scotia" be enshrined. However, it is my feeling that actually, in practice, it would be impossible for us to use in French the name "Nova Scotia", at least within the short term.
This Bill aimed at preserving the Latin name "Nova Scotia" is a little amazing to me. 1 would have no objections, my dear colleague, to using for instance another name in your language, were this to be the will of your constituents, of the people, in other words, or their tradition in your area. But as far as French-speaking people are concerned-on that Bill that points to the linguistic duality of our Canadian context and this is important-I must tell you that although I appreciate your reasons, and notwithstanding the use of other designations, either in French or in English, that may have been discussed in the past in this House, I feel that there are no grounds for suggesting that the name "Nova Scotia" might very easily be used in French. This would fly in the face of the historic evolution of our language and the name "Nouvelle-Ecosse" is to us a commonly used name that we find in our dictionaries, in our tradition and in our ways of speaking.
However, I can somewhat understand the rationale for your presenting such a Bill. I believe that your intentions are serious, that this might be a way for your community and your province to assert their identity. I am quite certain of this, but in view of the basic Canadian duality and the absolute need to respect this French and English duality in Canada, I would invite you to reconsider your proposal and to be very noble about it. I also invite you to apply the principles which inspire our new administration, this new Government elected last September 4, responsible for promoting a spirit of cooperation and reconciliation. I believe that this major reconciliation will occur among French and English-speaking Canadians-

I thank you for these words. In addition, Mr. Speaker, and of course I must always address you, but I am learning quickly, I see a Member who was not here a while earlier. In any case, I shall learn quickly, Mr. Speaker. But there, he has left. That is too bad; I could have shown him how quickly I am learning. Nevertheless, I can wish him a happy birthday. Today was his birthday. He has probably gone to celebrate.
To come back to my colleague, who wishes to assert this important cultural identity, we have an opportunity with 58 Members from Quebec and other French-speaking Members from other provinces to achieve this impossible dream- [English]
The impossible dream.

-which is Canada. This is an impossible dream, an ideal to be attained and we have the good luck to be members of a truly national party where we shall all respect one another, and I am certain that you yourself will make the necessary effort to ensure that this linguistic duality will become something positive and important for our community. I believe that you shall make the necessary efforts, and we shall do the same in spite of our own will to assert ourselves.
I want to point out that my position is also positive. I want the term "Nouvelle-Ecosse" to be kept in my language. This is now part of my culture. You are from "Nova Scotia", from "Nouvelle-Ecosse", but for me, you are part of Canada and of my culture. Indeed, it seems to me that there are people in your region-
Forgive me, Mr. Speaker, my comments are addressed to you. However, my colleague for Annapolis Valley-Hants (Mr. Nowlan) is showing so much understanding on this issue that I cannot avoid thinking occasionally that he must appreciate my comments on his Bill. As I was saying, there are also francophones in Nova Scotia, and during the all too few trips that I have made to this province I have noticed that French-speaking people in the area also use the term "Nouvelle-Ecosse". They do not say "Nova Scotia", except when they switch languages and speak English. They also do the same in English, or at least a few of them do because there are still many people who speak like that.
Designation of Nova Scotia
Mr. Speaker, it has been a great pleasure for me to speak to this motion, for I appreciate indeed the relevance of the nearly cultural remarks made on this subject by the Hon. Member for Annapolis Valley-Hants. Instead of voicing my opposition, I would again extend to him an open and cordial invitation so that we might all work together. I repeat, for once we have a unique opportunity.
History will record that outstanding reconciliation endeavour, perhaps through the expression "Nova Scotia", but the French words "Nouvelle-Ecosse" will add a new dimension, and I should say to my colleague that his remarkable understanding of this issue will enable all of us-

speechtext:
I would like to stress that taking the floor after my colleague who spoke with such eloquence is somewhat of a challenge for me, because he has summed up exactly how Quebecers feel about this bill. Since time immemorial, we in Quebec have used ... I can still recall grade school when we used the name "Nouvelle-Ecosse", because in the beginning, in the 17th century, many francophones lived there and still do now, and they are as attached to that name as they are to the region, their religion and their mother tongue, and many memories were passed from father to son. They were educated in French. They still are, and they still claim rights which will eventually be given to them. Those people of Nova Scotia, those residents of Nova Scotia who speak French see a very close link between their existence and the French name "Nouvelle-Ecosse." Naturally, the Hon. Member who moved this motion wants to keep the Latin name. Unfortunately, if we were to use the latin name - for francophones, it happens to be the same as the English name - we might very well raise serious doubts about our lengthy struggles for bilingualism and the mutual respect of two peoples that are beginning to live in harmony, I think, as the previous speaker so aptly emphasized.
I have often visited that beautiful province as a tourist, on holidays, and even some anglophones I met would use the French name when referring to Nova Scotia, claiming that the French name was the one they had heard first. This, of course, serves to remind our students, at least in Quebec, that the majority of the people living in that province at one time spoke French . . . many Canadians who speak only French, in Quebec and some parts of Ontario for instance, always say "Nouvelle-

November 30, 1984
Designation of Nova Scotia
Ecosse" and do not even know the expression "Nova Scotia". The use of this new name for them would therefore be felt as a sort of reconsideration of bilingualism, as my hon. friend said earlier; not only a reconsideration, but a step backward. They would understand that something is being taken away from them, a name which belongs to their heritage, which is part of their culture, which their families use in their daily lives, although the argument on the basis of the Latin expression could be justified. Many Canadians who do not use English at work and in their daily life would therefore be surprised to be deprived of the French name, and I am not sure they would understand that the idea is to return to the Latin name.
Your fine province might even suffer economically as a consequence of the elimination of the beautiful French name "Nouvelle-Ecosse", because many tourists visit your area every summer to enjoy your magnificent beaches, just as I did myself on three of four occasions.
Many Quebecers travel to that province to visit members of the armed forces who are stationed there in large numbers. They might find the change of name disturbing. Tourism might be adversely affected, not to mention the economy.
I ask you to reconsider your objection as did my colleague earlier. Some people like the French name of your fine province. They are more familiar with that name in my own province. They have been used to it for years. They would not understand a return to the Latin name since the name "Nouvelle-Ecosse" does not take away anything but gives to your area the additional characteristic of a bilingual name which makes people from both cultures feel at home. Not only would that bill be prejudicial to francophones in your own province, it could create an unfortunate impression with the French-speaking population abroad. In addition, it could have a negative effect on the people of Quebec who travel to your province each summer.
I think that there are sufficient grounds to review the bill and to withdraw it. It would be considered a significant move by French-speaking Canadians, and it would be harmful to that fine policy of bilingualism in effect for several years. When I am in Ottawa, thanks to simultaneous translation, I can hear distinguished speakers quote Shakespeare as well as former prime ministers such as Macdonald. I am pleased that you allow me to speak sometimes and quote Moliere and Racine, the great French authors as well as some comments by Hon. Members from Quebec. This sacred advantage should not be weakened. Such action is not perceived by me as being directed against us but it could be in some quarters. I feel that it is too touchy an issue dealing with bilingualism when a new party has just come into power with a majority in the ten provinces. A majority for the same party in the ten provinces is an unprecedented record!
There is a national consensus whereby this party represents a change, a new direction in the way this country is governed. Should this bill pass, it might jeopardize this whole policy,
which could be construed as a division, perhaps, within Parliament. I think we have worked together for too long, I would even say that we have fought together for too long in order to enjoy two cultures, so that our children may be educated in both official languages and appreciate Shakespeare as much as Moliere, as I said earlier, which has not been the case for us.
I dare not speak in English in this House yet for fear of offending a few ears, but thanks to the English classes I take regularly, you can be sure that within a year, I will be pleased to address this House in your language, the same way almost all the English-speaking members take French classes in order to communicate better. There is a will, a reality, a desire to be friendly and to live together, and we should ensure that such a small incident, for instance, like trying to change the French name of such a beautiful province as Nova Scotia may be wrongly interpreted by the public or by some people in the province, even in Quebec. Indeed, changing that French name would probably be considered a regressive step as far as bilingualism is concerned or the respect for both our communities which get along together in this House as well as throughout Canada, willing to carry on in this way for many years to come.
Therefore I ask you, my dear colleague, to reconsider this proposal to change, to remove the name "Nouvelle-Ecosse", and to continue to live in harmony with those beautiful designations we have for this province.
The experience we have been living for a few years with bilingualism, with the reform of the Constitution which was achieved, demonstrates a desire throughout Canada to see, as my colleague said, both cultures thrive as equal in the greatest respect. Again such a little incident could be misinterpreted.
Even if I understand very well the mover's motives, I would like him to reconsider this proposal.
I will not take any more of the time of the House, Mr. Speaker, to enable other Hon. Members to express their views.
I know that many speakers want to do so on this Friday afternoon, and I will give them a chance, but I wanted to indicate that I disagree with that proposal to remove the designation of "Nouvelle-Ecosse", precisely to avoid affecting the beautiful link which unites both cultures represented by the majority in this House.
