speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very glad to have the opportunity to speak for the first time in Private Members' hour in the Thirty-third Parliament. I would like to thank my friend and colleague, the Member for Annapolis Valley-Hants (Mr. Nowlan), for giving me this opportunity.
Last year about this same time I was fortunate enough to be in the House when the Hon. Member brought forward a similar Bill. I was impressed then by his eloquence and the
November 30, 1984

deep feeling with which he spoke of his province and how he felt it was so important to bring this particular Bill forward. I was impressed by his logic. I was impressed then and I am now. I was not in the House this year but 1 did have the opportunity to listen to his speech on the television in my office. I listened carefully because he argues well and with passion.
It may well be that many Members of the House are not familiar with what the Bill is all about. Perhaps, with the Speaker's permission, I could read the contents of the Bill. First, it is in the first session of the Thirty-third Parliament. It is a very small Bill, only two paragraphs, but it is an important Bill. The Bill is entitled Bill C-201, an Act respecting the official designation of "Nova Scotia". It reads:
Her Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate and House of Commons of Canada, enacts as follows:
1.	This Act may be cited as The Official Designation of Nova Scotia Act.
Clause 2 is the meat of the Bill. This is what is intended by the Act. It reads:
2.	In every place where the words "Nova Scotia" appear in any Act, regulation, statutory instrument, report, contract, lease, licence or other document the proper designation of such name in both official languages is and shall be "Nova Scotia".
This Bill may be short but it is very far-reaching and has great significance. I feel that I have an appreciation of the problems involved. I do not come from Nova Scotia like the Hon. Member for Timiskaming (Mr. MacDougall). I come from a place called the Okanagan Valley. We have heard from central Canada, Quebec and the Atlantic provinces on this issue, so I think it is time we heard from western Canada on this Bill.
The Okanagan Valley is in central British Columbia. The Hon. Member comes from the Annapolis Valley. These places have two things in common: they both grow very good apples. The Member for Annapolis Valley-Hants is nodding. At one time he had the courtesy to say that, although we both grow apples, perhaps we make better apple cider. I hope all Members have an opportunity to test that observation some day. Therefore, I feel I have some right to speak on this Bill this afternoon because we have that much in common.
Designation of Nova Scotia
Perhaps we have more than that in common. My children's maternal grandparents both came from Nova Scotia. Their maternal grandfather came from Antigonish. That is the home of the very famous university, St. Francis Xavier. I am proud to say that two of my children have gone to that university. I have some more interesting facts. My children's maternal grandfather began a newspaper called the Casket. It still exists and is the local newspaper in Antigonish.
The Member for Timiskaming spoke about Cape Breton earlier. My children's maternal grandmother came from an unlikely place called Myra's Gut. I see the Member is nodding. He recognizes that as a very fine small community. Therefore, with some justification and authority I can speak on this Bill because I too have a great love and affection for Nova Scotia, as I am sure all the Members of the House have. It has played a very important part in our history.
However, while I agree with the content of the Bill, it does not go far enough. The Hon. Member who spoke earlier mentioned the cost. This Bill proposes to change the name in every Act, regulation, statutory instrument, report, contract, licence, lease or other document. The cost of that would be prohibitive. We are now in a period of restraint. We are all being asked to cut back and put up with a little less than we would normally have. That is why we are doing the Member a service by postponing this Bill until another time when we are better able to bear the underlying cost which is inherent in the Bill.
I do not want to go into the constitutional problems, but I am sure that my friend from Annapolis Valley-Hants is aware of the difficulties in that regard. Mr. Speaker, I note the time and I would call it five o'clock.
